gkwreg 1.0.1.9000
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models

    Quantile Function for Generalized Kumaraswamy Distribution

    qgkw.Rd

    Calculates the quantile function (inverse CDF) of the Generalized Kumaraswamy distribution GKw(α, β, γ, δ, λ). For a given probability p, returns the value x such that P(X ≤ x) = p, where X follows a GKw distribution with the specified parameters.

    qgkw(
  p,
  alpha = as.numeric(c(1)),
  beta = as.numeric(c(1)),
  gamma = as.numeric(c(1)),
  delta = as.numeric(c(0)),
  lambda = as.numeric(c(1)),
  lower_tail = TRUE,
  log_p = FALSE
)

    Arguments

    p

    Vector of probabilities for which to compute quantiles. Values should be in (0,1), or in (-Inf,0] if log_p=TRUE.

    alpha

    Shape parameter α > 0 (scalar or vector). Controls the left tail behavior. Default: 1.0.

    beta

    Shape parameter β > 0 (scalar or vector). Controls the right tail behavior. Default: 1.0.

    gamma

    Shape parameter γ > 0 (scalar or vector). Affects the central shape. Default: 1.0.

    delta

    Shape parameter δ ≥ 0 (scalar or vector). Introduces additional flexibility. Default: 0.0.

    lambda

    Shape parameter λ > 0 (scalar or vector). Controls overall dispersion. Default: 1.0.

    lower_tail

    Logical; if TRUE (default), probabilities are P(X ≤ x), otherwise P(X > x).

    log_p

    Logical; if TRUE, probabilities are provided as log(p). Default: FALSE.

    Value

    Vector of quantiles corresponding to each probability in p. Returns:

    • 0 for probabilities ≤ 0 (or when log(p) = -Inf if log_p=TRUE)

    • 1 for probabilities ≥ 1 (or when log(p) = 0 if log_p=TRUE)

    • NA for invalid inputs (including p > 1 when log_p=TRUE, which would be log(p) > 0)

    • NA for invalid parameters (any of α, β, γ ≤ 0, δ < 0, or λ ≤ 0)

    Details

    According to Carrasco et al. (2010), the quantile function for the GKw distribution is derived by inverting the CDF MFd6iLVujrCTUGQ8o1z888FyzpdwUflI-$$ Q(p) = \{1 - (1 - (I^{-1}_{p}(\gamma, \delta+1))^{1/\lambda})^{1/\beta}\}^{1/\alpha} $$

    where \(I^{-1}_{p}(a, b)\) is the inverse regularized incomplete beta function.

    The implementation follows these steps to compute the quantile:

    1. Find y = qbeta(p, γ, δ+1)

    2. Compute $$v = y^(1/λ)$$

    3. Compute $$tmp = 1 - v$$

    4. Compute $$tmp2 = tmp^(1/β)$$

    5. Compute $$q = (1 - tmp2)^(1/α)$$

    Special care is taken at each step to handle numerical issues:

    • Boundary cases (p ≤ 0 or p ≥ 1) are handled directly

    • Intermediate results are checked for validity at each transformation step

    • Special cases where parameters equal 1 are optimized for speed and accuracy

    This implementation supports vectorized parameters, allowing any combination of vector and scalar inputs for all distribution parameters, with proper broadcasting for vectors of different lengths.

    References

    Kumaraswamy, P. (1980). A generalized probability density function for double-bounded random processes. Journal of Hydrology, 46(1-2), 79-88.

    Cordeiro, G. M., & de Castro, M. (2011). A new family of generalized distributions. Journal of Statistical Computation and Simulation, 81(7), 883-898.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Basic quantile calculation
qgkw(0.5, 2, 3, 1, 0, 1)  # Median of GKw(2,3,1,0,1)

# Computing multiple quantiles
probs <- c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9)
qgkw(probs, 2, 3, 1, 0, 1)  # Various percentiles

# Upper tail quantiles
qgkw(0.1, 2, 3, 1, 0, 1, lower_tail = FALSE)  # 90th percentile

# Log probabilities
qgkw(log(0.5), 2, 3, 1, 0, 1, log_p = TRUE)

# Vectorized parameters
alphas <- c(0.5, 1.0, 2.0)
betas <- c(1.0, 2.0, 3.0)
qgkw(0.5, alphas, betas)  # Will return 3 quantile values

# Verify inverse relationship with pgkw
p <- 0.75
x <- qgkw(p, 2, 3, 1, 0, 1)
pgkw(x, 2, 3, 1, 0, 1)  # Should be approximately 0.75
} # }
